title: Will filing a Chapter 13 allow me to catch up on my past due house payments??
question: I am 11 months or about $15k behind in house payments. My house is in foreclosure, but I have not received a sale date. I had a modification in the past and was told that I can't do another one until 24 months have passed. I am not sure how long it has been. I will have to look that up. My question is when I do get a sale date and File a Chapter 13, that will cause an automatic stay. However, will the plan let me make up those payments so that I can keep my home. I didn't have a job before and now have one to support my mortgage payment plus a payment plan. I have heard so many conflicting stories, like it won't save my home and the bank doesn't have to accept my past due payments. I need help.
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Bankruptcy court,Debt,Debt discharge,Bankruptcy and debt,Foreclosure,Car loan
answers:
One of the most common uses of chapter 13 is to allow home owners to bring their past due payments current over time. You will need to pay the ongoing payment, and the past due amount is spread out over a period of 36-60 months (3 to 5 years)
Don't go it alone. It is very hard to figure out the forms and requirements of a chapter 13 without an attorney. Depending upon your case, most chapter 13 attorneys will accept some of their fees through the plan, so your plan payment also pays them.

One common reason people file chapter 13 is to stop a foreclosure and allow them time to catch-up the delinquent mortgage payments. Chapter 13 does not require the lender's consent but it does require that you document your finances and explain how you can afford to pay your living expenses and keep your house. Chapter 13 is complicated so you should plan to have a lawyer help you with it.

Yes, you can do a Chapter 13 reorganization if you have the income to support it. What we need to do is see if you can support the plan as the attorney will have to convince a Judge and a Trustee that you can do it.

There is a lot more that would have to be looked at to confirm that you can do it. Also an attorney would want to look at all your other debts like car loans, taxes and credit cards just to name a few.

Do yourself a huge favor and see a quality bankruptcy attorney to find out what can be done for you and what is protected. Your case would be filed in the Bankruptcy Court in Sacramento. I would recommend you find a quality bankruptcy attorney by looking at Avvo's ratings for Sacramento attorneys.

You could also look at the CA State bar website for a Certified Bankruptcy Law Specialist in Sacramento. Most attorneys will give you are free initial consultation. I have provided a link to the state bar below.

Another potential source for finding a good attorney would be through a search of the National Association of Consumer Bankruptcy Attorneys (NACBA.org) to find a good local attorney. Again, I have provided a link below.
No matter how good an attorney is rated, if you are not comfortable with the attorney when you meet, move on to another attorney. Also, if the attorney uses a paralegal to do the initial appointment, move on because you are just a number and a dollar sign. If this is how you are treated when they are trying to get your money, you can be certain it is not going to get better after they get your money.

Do NOT use an attorney that does anything other than bankruptcy and consumer law and/or foreclosure law. Part-time bankruptcy attorneys are, sadly, never expert enough to do the job right. This is a specialized field and you should go with an attorney who practices solely in that specialty. Choose based on skill rather than price. A bad attorney will cost you way more in the long run. Never hire to veterinarian's assistant to do brain surgery on you and never hire a non-specialist to do a specialists job. Get the right attorney to begin with.

I hope this helps you.
